gitActivity.lastCommitMessage: Add AI layer for smart test generation and explanations
recentCommits: Add AI layer for smart test generation and explanations
Add LDAP injection patterns for ldap3 library
Improve pattern precision for SQL injection and XSS
Add LLM pattern generator and improve SQL/path patterns
Add pattern improvement tooling and import Semgrep patterns
Add output security tests and fix benchmark thresholds
Add README, fix type errors, complete Week 6 tasks
Add blindspot tests for concurrency and edge cases

suggestionHistory.suggestion: Run the OWASP Python benchmark and analyze results. Use: npm run benchmark:quick, then npx tsx scripts/owasp-benchmark.ts run python. Review the scorecard for categories with <80% recall and use the LLM pattern generator to improve them.

Review the codebase for security issues and API design. Check: 1) Input validation in CLI commands, 2) Path traversal protection in Scanner, 3) Template injection risks in TemplateRenderer, 4) Error message information disclosure. Focus on src/cli/index.ts, src/core/scanner/scanner.ts, and src/templates/renderer.ts.

Review the codebase for production readiness. Check for security issues, performance bottlenecks, and code quality. Focus on: error handling in CLI commands, input validation for file paths, memory usage in AST parsing, and any hardcoded values that should be configurable.

Run 'npm run build && npm run lint && npm run typecheck' to verify all gates pass. If successful, commit the 6 pending changes with message 'Complete BUILD phase - all tests passing'. Then use midas_advance_phase to move to SHIP.

Run npm test to execute the full test suite. Look for any failing tests and fix them. Focus on: 1) AST parser tests that require WASM setup, 2) Scanner integration tests, 3) CLI command tests. If tree-sitter WASM tests fail, check if npm run setup:wasm was run.

Run npm test and check test results. Fix any failing tests, focusing on: 1) Category definition validation tests 2) Scanner gap detection logic 3) Template rendering with variable substitution 4) AST pattern matching if WASM is set up
Run npm test to execute the full test suite. Look for any failures or coverage gaps, and fix any issues found. If all tests pass, we're ready to advance to the SHIP phase.

Run `npm test` to execute all tests. Focus on any failures - likely areas include AST parser tests (if WASM not loaded), path handling in Windows, or async timing issues. Use `npm test -- --reporter=verbose` for detailed output.

Run npm test to execute the full test suite. Look for any failing tests, focus on the modified files today (all-categories.test.ts, security.test.ts). Fix any TypeScript errors or test failures that come up.

Run npm test to check test suite status. Focus on failing tests first - look for TypeScript errors, missing fixtures, or WASM setup issues. Fix errors starting with unit tests before integration tests.

Run npm test to execute the full test suite. Look for any failing tests, particularly in the modified files (all-categories.test.ts, security.test.ts, migrator.ts, renderer.ts). Focus on fixing test failures related to category counts or schema validation.

Run `npm test` to execute the full test suite. Look for any failing tests, particularly in the recently modified all-categories.test.ts and security.test.ts. If all tests pass, we can advance to DEBUG. If any fail, fix them based on the error messages.

Run the test suite with `npm test` to verify all tests pass after adding the 6 new security categories. If any fail, fix them focusing on: 1) Updated category counts in tests, 2) Schema validation for new categories, 3) Detection pattern matching. Then run coverage report with `npm run test:coverage`.

Debug the failing security category tests. Run 'npm test tests/categories/definitions/all-categories.test.ts' and check if all 16 security YAML files exist in src/categories/definitions/security/. The test expects: sql-injection, xss, path-traversal, csrf, xxe, command-injection, deserialization, ldap-injection, ssrf, timing-attack, plus the 6 new ones (hardcoded-secrets, auth-failures, rate-limiting, data-exposure, file-upload, dependency-risks).

Run `npm test` to check test suite status. If tests fail, identify the failures and fix them one by one. Focus on: 1) Import path issues 2) Mock setup for tree-sitter WASM 3) File system operations in tests. Once all tests pass, we can move to DEBUG step.
Run the test suite and fix any failing tests. Start with `npm test` to see failures, then fix them one by one. Focus on the core modules first: pattern-matcher, scanner, and CLI commands.

Implement the --write flag for the generate command to save generated test files. Read the cached gaps from .pinata/cache.json, generate tests using the TemplateRenderer, then write each test to its suggested path (creating directories as needed). Show a summary of files created.

Implement the 'pinata generate' command in src/cli/index.ts. Parse the --gaps, --category, and --domain options, load detected gaps from a previous analyze run (consider caching results), filter gaps based on options, then use the TemplateRenderer to generate test files. For now, just output the generated tests to console with --dry-run as default.

Implement the analyze command in src/cli/index.ts. Connect it to the Scanner class, parse the command options (path, domains, severity, output format), create scanner instance with CategoryStore, run the scan, and format results based on output type (terminal/json/markdown). Handle errors and display progress with ora spinner.

Implement the Scanner class in src/core/scanner/scanner.ts that orchestrates codebase analysis. It should: 1) Accept a target directory and scan options, 2) Use PatternMatcher to scan files for category detections, 3) Aggregate results by category with file locations and confidence scores, 4) Return a structured ScanResult with found gaps, coverage metrics, and a pinata score. Include methods for scanDirectory(), aggregateResults(), and calculateScore(). Reference gameplan Week 11 tasks.
